abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Infrastructure for
            Territorial Development Project for Chile were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            moderate; Bank performance was satisfactory and borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            includes: the design and implementation of complex projects
            involving substantial involvement of specialists in several
            disciplines requires above average resource allocations. The
            design of fairly complex technical assistance for planning
            in projects with national coverage in poor rural areas might
            require higher than usual preparation in terms of a thorough
            assessment of existing community needs and available optimal
            social delivery systems. The right amount of flexibility in
            project design and implementation might be a key to project
            success. In retrospect the project was too specific on
            certain areas thus imposing a level of rigidity that
            challenged its viability.  Institutions with a strong
            mindset and with the capacity to manage a decentralized
            program of interventions as well as the selection of
            territories with ample social capital were a key to project
            success. Managing expectations should become an integral
            part of projects pioneering substantive and complex changes
            in servicing rural communities. Inclusion of productive
            activities in the project might add a level of complexity in
            design and implementation but could be the key for project
            success. Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) should remain a
            high priority during both project design and implementation
            and weaknesses in the original arrangements and
            responsibilities should be addressed as soon as detected.
